titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 14 August 1864.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 14 August 1864
titleStmt.author: William B. Anderson

note.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated August 14, 1864 from Cincinatti and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on two sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 10 inches tall (19.5 x ? 25cm) and is unruled. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream).

projectDesc.p: This letter, written on August 14, 1864 by William B. Anderson to his wife is similar in style and content to the 21 other letters he wrote from 1862 to 1864. These letters, housed in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library of the Ohio State University, tend to touch on two broad topics: household correspondence and business correspondence. Mixed in with these topics are frequent mentions of 19th century letter writing conventions and Anderson's appologies for breaking them due to his frequent haste in writing. Anderson also writes about the logistics of his trips, which are often complicated by the war.

Much of this particular letter is taken up with Anderson's account of the past few days. His frustration over both having to hire men to watch his freight and then being forced to sleep with the tobacco is evident. In this letter, like many others, Anderson takes care of business with his wife and informs her of what he has done for their business. It appears he has paid several people while on his trip and informs, or perhaps only reminds, Louisa that he has left the money in the "Big Pocket Book".

Another interesting part of this letter is his sentimental request that his wife send him pictures of the children, "I would like you to send me one each of a likeness of you and the children to look at occasionally." Anderson seems close to his family and, at times, impatient to hear from them. In several of the other letters, he mentions that he did not get letters. In this letter, he goes as far as to give his wife a new address to send letters to so that he may recieve them earlier.

One wonders what happened to Louisa's letters to her husband. It is likely that he kept them, being so eager to receive them, but also that they have been lost or perhaps damaged. It is also likely that Louisa was responsible for the careful preservation of her husband's letters. The Rare Books and Manuscripts library of the Ohio State University was able to purchase the letters through a dealer. They were purchased, in part, because they provided a unique and personal perspective into the Civil War period of the United States. These letters should be of interest, not only to Civil War historians, but to students of business transactions, those interested in the history of letter writing, and people generally interested in the time period.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.
To view the project's complete markup guidelines, click here.

At the time of publication (6 June 2006), the XML and XSL files related to this edition were stored in an XML publishing system operated by Humanities Information Systems (HIS), College of Humanities, The Ohio State University. For more information about HIS, see http://his.osu.edu/. Most image, audio, and video files linked to, or embedded in, this edition via <figure> elements were stored in the Media Manager system maintained by the Colleges of Arts and Sciences of The Ohio State University. For more information about the Media Manager, see https://mediamanager.osu.edu/.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/ To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 14 August 1864.

div1.p: Anderson informs his wife that he has arrived in Louisville, KY. He reports that a canal was closed and tells his wife that he was forced to hire men to keep some tobacco safe and slept with it on a subsequent night incase it rained. Anderson reports the local weather and asks her to send him pictures of their children. He also advises her of a new address to send letters to.

Yours of 9th Came safe to hand
I was pleased to hear from you. We arrived
from Louisville1 on Friday Evening made a
quick trip but very little Money when we got
to Louisville the Canal was closed to repare
and we came back with but 1/4 of a load
on account of the R Road here having Teleg
=raphed down to not ship up any more Frt
as they were blocked full of Frt & could not
take it in the Depots consequently could not
take it off the wharf I put our Tobacco off
Yesterday & Last night had to hire men &
put it onboard the Boat today to Keep it safe
for fear of rain now I have to lay here with it in
the Boat till Tuesday & then I am to commence to
load again for Louisville I have a little better
prospect than before. I left you that Pittsbg2
Money & put it in that Big Pocket Book I Took
the Gov money & Pd Mr Hamilton3 the 168$ to pay
the Taxes with. I have not seen the Old Lady4
yet it has been Excessively hot today & has rained
a little & is Cloudy with prospects of rain. I have
been Tollerable well since I wrote last. I have
no news of any importance to write about
I would like you to send me one of Each
of the Likenesses of You & the children5 to look
at occasionally I may go below from
Louisville this trip if the Canal is open
though it is very uncertain

Direct your letters to me in Care
of Harry Davidson and co6 Cincinnati Ohio
instead of Barker Hart & Cook7 & I will
get them in the night as well as day
for they keep a man to sleep in the store
Kiss all the little ones and tell them
to be good

let me hear often from you & tell
me how the crops look &c. &c. get
a girl soon as you can & take
care of your own health & that of the
children

P.S. I will drop you a line again
when I leave here
Yours WBA

div1.head: Notes
div1.note:
1.
Map of Louisville, KYClick to view a map of Louisville, KY 1876 Bird's eye view of Louisville, Kentucky 1876.

2.
Map of Pittsburgh, PAClick to view a map of Pittsburgh, PA ca. 1871Pittsburgh, Allegheny & Birmingham
4.Possibly a refrence to William B. Anderson's mother-in-law: Ann (Woolslayer) FischgensHistory of Allegheny County,298-299
5.William B. Anderson and his wife, Louisa had 5 children: William Y., Anna M., John L., Robert C., and Harry C.History of Allegheny County,298-299
6.Unidentifiable, possibly a refrence to a lawyer's firm or purchasing firm similar to Barker, Hart & Cook.
7.This is likely a refrence to the same Barker, Hart & Cook, who, in 1862, purchased a boat in Cincinatti, OH. It is unclear what kind of company Barker, Hart & Cook is.The Allegheny River,239
